description.text:
My home NAS server is about 6 years old and has 4 hot-swap SSD bays which are used for the data volumes. The OS was installed on a Compact Flash card, which despite giving excellent service, got fritzed when I turned it off to clean the office (moral: never turn things off if they're working and covered in dust!) The CF card was in an adapter which was mounted on the white pegs you can see in the photos.

The quickest and cheapest option to get the server up and running again was to replace the CF with an SSD. Having nothing proprietary to mount the SSD onto though meant I was able to bring 3D printing to the rescue with the attached Blender and STL model. Quite a long print, but light, perfectly-sized and all the holes lining up means it does just what I needed (though I'm not actually going to use the ReadyCache disk - that was just to check dimensions).

There's a lip round the back outside edge for a little extra stability though I dont think it's really necessary. The pegs on the back are to provide a stand-off and match the depth of the mounting pegs in my chassis - you could leave them off, or adjust their height to suit.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

I designed this Adapter in order to connect an Nema 17 stepper motor to an aluminium profile. (see pictures for that :) ) 
This part works as a bracket to change the holding screws from the front to the bottom.
The four front screws for attaching the motor to the plate are M3x10mm. The holes in the ground fit M5 screws.
Edit: I uploaded a second rounded version for bstott :) I know that its still not perfect since the critical parts are not rounded but I had little time to redesign the whole thing to make it more stable...

Get a 3d printer, print this part... pretty much straightforward
Get at least 4 M3x10 screws.

title: Sinclair ZX Spectrum+  improved ribbon cable clips for membrane keyboard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Repairing the membrane keyboard of my Sinclair Spectrum ZX+ microcomputer (vintage from 1980's) I noticed that there are several layers that must be well placed to ensure the best contact of the different little metal paths of each layer of the two keyboard ribbon cables.

I have designed new wider clips to improve and press the ribbon cables to the case. Because they now have more surface the contact between the layers of the membrane keyboard is better.

In addition you can help to this using a little portion of E.V.A. foam as is shown in the pictures.

The different designs include a flat version, another with edges like the original clips and a copy of these (called normal) for replacement.

The files available to download are:

  • zx_spectrum+_large_clip_keyboard_flex_sxs.stl
  • zx_spectrum+_large_clip_keyboard_flex_flat_sxs.stl
  • zx_spectrum+_large_clip_normal_keyboard_flex_sxs.stl
  • zx_spectrum+_large_clip_normal_keyboard_flex_flat_sxs.stl
  • zx_spectrum+_short_clip_keyboard_flex_sxs.stl
  • zx_spectrum+_short_clip_keyboard_flex_flat_sxs.stl
  • zx_spectrum+_short_clip_normal_keyboard_flex_sxs.stl
  • zx_spectrum+_short_clip_normal_keyboard_flex_flat_sxs.stl

For printing I have used a 0.4 nozzle with 0.3 layer height.

Although the original screws could be used with the new clips, it would be better if you use another longer ones specially if you combine the clips with E.V.A. foam.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

P3 Steel MM Large

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Nozzle: 0.4 mm - Layer height: 0.3 mm - Shell thickness: 0.8 mm - Bottom/Top thickness: 1.2 mm

Infill:

40

Notes:

The piece has been printed with PLA 1.75 filament using Cura slicer software with a 0.4 mm nozzle.

No supports required.

description.text:
Aren't you tired of battery adapters for LED torches which don't fit, and leave the batteries an amount of slack that they can move around freely in the housing, to an extent that LEDs flicker or change mode when subjecting the torch to even slight acceleration? Especially the dual supply torches, for (n x 18650) or (n x 3xAAA), seem to suffer consistently from inadequately dimensioned adapters. So does the in principle quite nice 26650 zoom torch, which can be used with either one or two cells, purchased during discount action on banggood (http://www.banggood.com/MECO-XM-L-T6-3600LM-Zoomable-LED-Flashlight-2x18650-p-982567.html, was around $7 for this huge bugger then) - the AAA adapters I repurposed immediately, as I'm using the torch with 18650 cells. Spacers for conversion to 18650 cells were provided - but those are just completely off measure. Time for replacement.
As the problem with those adapters has been identified as "recurring", the solution ought to address this. Therefore customiser. Here it is: the rattle stifler.
Presets are for the flashlight shown above: Two spacers, each cell sized, to accommodate use with either one or two cells. One spacer turned such that rim points towards contact spring, rim of other spacer goes towards rear cap switch. Inner diameter fits the Panasonic NCR18650A cells, shown in the picture, spot-on.

Problems, shortcomings

known problems fixed in v0.03

Version history

Battery spacer, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1801936
v0.01 2016oct01, ls (http://www.thingiverse.com/Bushmills): initial version
v0.02 2016oct01, ls added twist, some factoring.
v0.03 2016oct02, ls fixed fin positions on jacket, made thickness of base with rim customisable
v0.04 2016oct02, ls fin position calculation compacted and simplified
v0.05 2016oct03, ls simplified punching intersected parts (dropped "difference()")

This was a job with emphasis on use of these tools:

  • caliper
  • text editor
  • cup of coffee

description.text: This clip is designed to allow the attachment of peripheral light sources to the MakerBot Digitizer's crossbeam. This is a single component of an assembly I am currently working on. When completed, this assembly will allow the mounting of a lighting system with adjustments for brightness and angle. Hopefully this will allow an easier way to find the best "light recipe" for the MakerBot Digitizer's sensitive camera in a variety of environments.

After realizing the sensitivity of the MakerBot Digitizer's camera, I found that a light placed at a specific angle behind the camera's field of view greatly enhanced the quality of my scan. I was using a simple banker's lamp positions behind the camera with the shade resign on the crossbeam. This arrangement was too inconvenient to use on a consistent basis. So, I decided to design a lighting system that attaches directly to the crossbeam of the Digitizer.  
After taking measurements of the crossbeam and drawing a quick circuit schematic, I sketched a rough draft of the design in AutoCad.   
This clip is a prototype component for a larger assembly, which will utilize two (2) of these accessory clips. The two clips will support a small structure which will house the electronic components of the lighting system.  
More to follow! Keep Makin' Stuff!

Jig for cutting worm type pinch wheel on M8 bolt for Wade's geared nema 17 extruder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1794 with a drill, but without using a vise.

Print two of these and load with 608 bearings. Clamp a scrap board to your workbench and screw these bearing blocks to it. Chuck the M8 bolt in your drill chuck and use a round file to add a 1 - 1.5mm grove in your bolt where it will match up to the filament path. Remove bolt from drill and insert through the bearings. Chuck up the M3 tap and clamp / hold drill as shown in picture. Original instructions http://objects.reprap.org/wiki/Development:Geared_Nema17_Extruder The attached revision is about 4mm thinner than the ones pictured to allow a little more freedom in bolt length.

title: Dodge Ram Vent Mount for iPhone

description.text: [ I've uploaded the new design which compensates for the weight causing the vent to close. The vent still closes, but the slope of the face leaves the phone at a viewable angle ] This is a vent mount for an iPhone that fits the vents for a 2006 Dodge Ram 1500 The phone case is from Thing:4382 ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4382 ). Kudos to aylr for such a great design. I am using his iPhone Bike Mount but wanted to be able to leverage that case with a mount for my truck My files do not include the case. You will want to download aylr's case and print it for use with this vent mount

1) print the case from thing:4382 and the parts from this thing
2) attach the 2 legs to the base using 2 M3x12 screws
3) attach the base to the phone case mount using 1 M3x12 the holes are such that you won't need a nut, but I'm not sure how long that will last 4) insert phone in the case from alyr's thing:4382
5) mount the vent mount in the vent
6) attach the phone case to the vent mount I'm going to give mine an acetone dip before use to try to strengthen it a bit. I'm not sure I'm that good of a designer. IE, don't cross a bridge that I build....I sure wouldn't. If you improve this design (and please do), let me know and I'll use yours instead of mine

This is a wine rack for an IKEA KALLAX shelf, it can be lasered/CNCd from any thickness of plywood, remember to se the thickness in the source though!

Suggested toolpath, I used a Epilog Legend 36EXT 75W laser:

  1. Open the .scad file and set your plywood thickness in ply_size_mm = 6;. There is no need to account for the width of the laser beam, it usually gives you the tolerance you need to be able to slide it together once cut.
  2. Make sure //assemble = true; is commented to get the 2D view, hit F6 and export all the parts as dxf (NOT SVG).
  3. Import the parts into inkscape and lay them out on a page that fits your plywood/laser bed. Pay attention to the direction of the wood-grain on your ply.
  4. Set the parts to no fill and a solid stroke of 0.025mm.
  5. Save as (not export) the pages in PDF form and print them to the laser cutter.
  6. Optionally glue the rack together, mine is quite sturdy as it is.

The pre-exported DXF and SVG files are for 6mm ply.

I designed this in openscad using the 2D primitives; square(), circle(), etc.. I work with two assemblies of these 2D modules, one flat which I export to cut. The other an assembled, extruded, 3D view of the thing. I switch between the two using a variable. It's a really nice way to make laserable things.

comments.text: I've parameterised the ply thickness and updated the source.

Okey, this might not be interesting for most unless you actually have the said USB-Hub which I included in the picture. You might have one that's slightly different tough, so I've added the SKP file from Sketchup so that you can change it into a better fit for you.

The holder is a simple design, tough so far one of my most advanced self drawn ones. It's designed to have the usb-hub slide into place, even tough admittedly the side arms could have been a bit further to get a better grip. It also have screw holes so that you should be able to fit small screws through it and attach it to the wall. I also added a picture of the finished product with the usb-but attached and screwed onto the wall.

This gearbox was designed to be a fun and easy build for a 3-D printer like the Makerbot 2. It has moving gears and uses 3-D printed bolts to hold the gearbox together.

description.text:
This is a monitor mount for a 4 camera vehicle mounted system. All 4 cameras record constantly. I purchased this system on ebay. Here is the description line if you are interested.
9" QUAD MONITOR WITH DVR 4 x SIDE CAMERAS SAFETY SYSTEM FOR TRUCK TRAILER RV
I put it on a wheel lift wrecker I use in my business. The constant recording give me the security that what takes place is available to show police or judges later should the need arise. The cabover truck I have really doesn't need a rear view mirror with all 4 cameras on so using the mirror for a mount point seemed appropriate. Keep in mind some or maybe even most rear view mirrors that are mounted on the inside roof will have a break away feature to protect you in a crash. The added weight of the monitor may mean you have to defeat this function in some way. This is quite a specialized thing so I doubt many will find it useful, however, if you do this is an excellent model and it should work on many mirrors. The lower side has a place for zip ties to fix it on more securely. It should be noted that mine has been in use for months without the zip ties and it is just fine. This is an ABS model. Don't attempt to use PLA as it will sag under the weight when the inside cab temperature rises in the summer months.

Yes

Notes:

Use ABS only due to the inside of the cab getting too hot in the summer months.

title: Hario Skerton coffee mill electric screwdriver adapter

description.text:
This is another adapter that allows to motorise a Hario Skerton manual coffee grinder with a standard hex shaft electric screwdriver (like an IXO as shown in the photo).

The difference with the other models that can be found on Thingiverse, is that this one can be mounted without having to remove the handle or nut. This means the grinder won't fall apart if you topple it over, and you can switch to manual at any time.

Do not use any tool that spins faster than about 3 revolutions per second, this could damage your Skerton.

It is obvious that this part must be printed to be as strong as possible, because it will need to withstand quite a bit of force. Any type of filament will probably do, but I recommend ABS or PETG. Print it nice and slow with not too thick layers, with the fan disabled except when absolutely necessary (e.g. for the hex shaft which could become a blob without extra cooling). Use a high infill, at least 50%, although 100% may be the best choice. Print with a high number of perimeters for extra strength, I used 4.

A PETG model I printed was able to withstand the force of the IXO being jammed on a stubborn coffee bean, but it eventually broke at a weak point caused by me messing up the fan settings. I printed another one in rigid.ink ABS filament, and that one held for quite a long time until I broke it by making a wrong move with the IXO. I was actually amazed at how strong a home-3D-printed part can be.

Update 2016/12/30: I added an alternative model that accepts a hex shaft, this should be less prone to breaking. Even if you don't have a metal hex shaft handy, you can still print the provided 1-inch shaft, which might be more robust than the upwards-pointing shaft that is integrated in the other model, because the layers will be perpendicular to the torque forces. Still, you will need a damn strong filament and print with many perimeters to give this shaft any chances of survival. I tried one in ABS which broke eventually. I then tried one in PLA, which to my surprise has held up so far.

I'll be honest about the fact that this more of a novelty than something really practical, unless you can have it printed in metal or some other nearly indestructible material. Even the strongest of typical filaments will not be able to survive if you tilt your electric drill too much, which puts undue strain on the base of the hex shaft and breaks it. Even the alternative model that accepts a separate hex shaft and is much more robust, still is not terribly practical. If you are too lazy to grind your coffee manually, buy a motorised grinder ;)

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The photos show the part printed with rigid.ink PETG and silver ABS.

Next to the regular models, another one with a pre-made tiny support is provided, which can help with blobby filaments to get an accurate print of the small overhang at the bottom (just cut off the support with a knife).

If you want to print the hex shaft, a raft is highly recommended because you should print the shaft with many perimeters or a high infill, and this will increase the risk of it warping during printing. Print it with the strongest filament you have. The shaft STL model has exact dimensions, you may need to sand it down a little bit for it to fit in your drill.

remixed_from.title: Rear lens cap for Nikon F-mount, fully printable.

description.text:
This is a 3D printable slide projector that will work with a Nikon SB-600 flash.  
The goal of this project is to sync the slide projector with my camera so it will project an image or pattern when I take a picture.  
For the projector to work you need to attach a flash to the back and a lens to the front to focus the light.  
I find using a flashlight to get everything set up and in focus is a good idea, then switch to the flash.  
I designed some custom slides with patterns for creating different effects. Mounted slide film works great too.  
This model is set up for use with a Nikon Speedlight SB-600 and a Nikon lens mount. I've been using a bower 85mm 1.4 lens to test. But other lenses work. You just new to be able to open the aperture manually. Newer Nikon "G" lenses wouldn't work as well.  
This project was created in Tinkercad, and I used Meshmixer to generate support material for printing.

The distance between the slide slot and the front of the Camera mount in the "Flange distance " for a nikon camera it is 46.5mm.  
This distance is important for the lens to focus properly on the image plane. I'm not sure if it's as important going the other way and projecting through the lens. But I used it.

comments.text: This is really cool! Gives me SO many ideas of things I can do with my dad's old slides. He has so many, I'll bet even he forgets what he has. I remember sitting in the basement as a kid and watching slide shows with the family (and sometimes friends)...oh the good 'ol days. Now we 'just' sit in front of a screen to view pictures so much of the time. Not nearly the same kind of experience. Using his slides for something involving him now, would be the neatest Father's Day present. Glad I found this now so I have time to get the shots I want. I am not a 'great' photographer, but it will be fun doing this, all the same. Thanks for sharing. You have sparked some creative ideas :)

title: Cookie stamper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
One acquaintance of mine presented 3D-printed stamp for this cookie stamp from Tescoma. See that page for recipes and video on usage.

I don't have it and it's easier to design and print my own, than to go to the store for the Tescoma one.

To make your own stamp insert, just create cylinder of 3 mm height and 45 mm diameter and put your motif on it, extruded by 1.6 mm. Don't forget to mirror it! If you want to plain text one, you can use the OpenSCAD file, just modify the stamp_text variable.

Everything is parametric, so if you want to make bigger or smaller cookies, just modify the variables in OpenSCAD file.

The pictures with green horse stamp are of the first version with a bit worse usability.

Everything is held together with friction. You might want to adjust the stamp_clearance according to your printer precision. It should be a tight fit, the hole in center is there for pushing it out.

There is additional set of X-mass related stamp inserts from GummiBear.

  • Added better quality rendering to parts rendering script

title: 120mm Case Fan Duct for PCI/ATX Expansion Slot

description.text:
A duct that adapts a 120mm fan to blow out the PCI/ATX expansion slots. The exhaust opening takes up 3 slots, with a 25mm-thick fan taking one more slot. The combined assembly takes up exactly 4 slots of width. The bottom of the duct should clear both PCI-E and taller conventional PCI slots.

You can mount the fan with fan screws or cable-ties.

Print with the largest flat side (the side opposite the one where the fan mounts) on the build plate. Supports are needed for a very small overhanging part of the PCI bracket. In Cura, the setting for supports is "Touching Build Plate". This keeps it from generating supports between the vent fins, where they are difficult to remove. If you don't have this option, it might be better to turn off supports altogether and let the bracket sag a little.

Versions:

  • V1.0 - Initial revision and the versions you see in the pictures above.
  • V1.1 - Thickened PCI slot brackets from 1.2mm to 2.0mm. This may be too thick to fit between the slot between your motherboard and case, so measure it before printing.
  • V1.1_rotated - Same as 1.1, but rotated to lay flat on the build plate. (Z-axis faces up)
  • V1.1b - Branch of V1.1. The tongue that slides between the edge of the motherboard and the wall of the case has been shortened to accommodate 200 mm diameter build plates. (See the last two pictures that have a white background) This version does not need supports.
  • V1.1c - Branch of V1.1. The opening where the fan mounts points the other direction. (Away from the CPU instead of towards it)

Source files via an Onshape link are provided so you can modify the duct if needed using a free Onshape account. All versions are accessible in Onshape. You need to log in to see the entire version history.

The PCI and ATX mechanical specifications were helpful when designing this thing.

Onshape Links:

  • V1.0, V1.1
  • V1.1b

remixed_from.title: HICTOP Prusa i3 Cable Chain mounts

title: Alunar i3 Cable Chain with Mounts

description.text:
I used the Hictop Prusa i3 but found that I needed everything moved backwards by 10mm so that it did not interfere with the Z rods. My x axis bearing and hot end mount on this printer also needed a different attachment for the carriage as it only uses 2 bolts on the top linear bearing units. Using the spare bearing mount holes I decided to attach the end of the cable chain mount to here. The stepper motor end is pushed back 10mm as well from the original and mounting location is changed to reflect this alteration.

Make sure the chain does not exceed or bump into the parts at the top of your Z axis such as the Knob. You may have to remove a few mm from the max Z height of your machine. I don't print large objects so this was fine for me. Height now is 165mm from 185mm.

Still testing this piece.

title: Desiccant canister to dry 3D printing filament

description.text: Some 3D printing filaments absorb water from the air. It's recommended to store such filaments in an air-tight container with a packet of desiccant. This screw-top canister is designed to hold dry rice or silica beads as a desiccant, and to fit in the 51mm center hole of the filament reel.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

Notes:

I designed the bottom part upside-down. Please rotate the bottom part 180 degrees (turn it upside-down) before printing.

The parts are designed to print without any support. I printed in PLA.

The cutout fins made the cuts

The cutoutFins design file contains the fin designs I used to cut out the holes in the top, bottom, and sides. Note that the top and bottom cuts are 1.5mm instead of 1mm, to accomodate the overextruded first layers of the top and bottom - that is, 1mm slots on the first layers of a print tend to be much narrower than 1mm.

The top and bottom are each constructed from 3 parts: the basic cylinder, the cutoutFins which are subtracted to make the holes, and finally the thread.

comments.text: I'll have a group o kids coming to library to do these :) Couple of question: So does 6 shells in Cura mean "wall line count" 6? What about top leyers/bottom leyers? Also 6? Or zero, because infill is 100%? Any other great tips? What is the best oil after degreasing?
comments.author: Sankku

comments.text: According to what I read the "number of shells" is dependent on your nozzle width, mine is 0.4 so to get "6 shells" I would multiply 0.4 * 6 = 2.4. That 2.4 then goes into Cura under "Shell" -> "Wall Thickness" -> "2.4". You can also make Cura show you "Wall Line Count" but if you change the number it will complain it's a calculated number so it's better to do the math yourself and change the wall thickness. comments.text: He clearly outlines the quality differences in the bearings. If you don't get a quality bearing, it will have poor spin for this application. I've been able to make the cheap 608zz's spin up to 60 seconds by degreasing long, as he suggests, but they still aren't as good as the Red's brand regular or Ceramic. You have to remove the outer shields of the cheap all metal ones with a small screw driver or pocket knife and soak in the degreaser for 30 minutes minimum (you can get engine degreaser from any auto shop or home depot - get the strong stuff). For a quicker fix, just spray some WD-40 into the bearing (again, you need to remove at least 1 shield/cover), but it won't be nearly as good as a full degrease.
comments.author: thonghh_910

comments.text: I model mostly in SOLIDWORKS. This model could have been done in any other solid modeling software such as Autodesk NX, Catia, or pro-e. The only hard part was designing the partial fillets around the edges. I accomplished this by doing a full face fillet and cutting the frame with two planes. I would suggest to learn SOLIDWORKS first. Many great tutorials online for free.

comments.text: Robert, I'm printing on the Monoprice maker select v2. My prints are coming out very nice once I checked my bed level. The first layer was good an the layers after that were a mess. If I had to guess, either your too tight to the print bed or you're having extrusion problems. Shortly after I got my printer I started having first layer issues. Turned out that the set screw on  the extruder gear was loose so it wasn't pushing the filament through. I am no expert in 3d world just a beginner but wanted to share my experience just in case it could help.

description.text:
We recently purchased an aeropress for our upcoming RV trip to the US. As the supplied filter holder doesn't hold the filters in place during travel I decided to create an extension travel 'collar' to attach to the aeropress. Obviously I thought this was the best idea ever and no-one else could possibly have come up with such an awesome plan. Then I checked thingiverse. Damn you @kdpainter (damn you, but thank you!)

So I've taken the great parts that kdpainter has created and using openSCAD merged them together, removed the separators and added a single one in... the result? An extension collar to store the filters in during travel, and to hold the filters once unpacked.

It might be my printer, but the original files printed slightly too big (they do fit, but tricky to get in/out), so I found printing at 99% made for a better fit.

title: RTIC or YETI Two Piece Handle

description.text:
I wanted a custom printed handle for my RTIC cup, but couldn't print some of the others available because of bed size. This one is made in two pieces so my MP mini could handle it. A single 1/4" bolt of at least 1" in length is needed along with a nut. A small protrusion from the hoop fits in a keyway in the handle to prevent the handle from spinning.

I printed both at around 60% infill for heft and strength. I printed the handle sticking straight up. The quality was good, but the strength might be better if printed horizontally with supports.

The print fits my RTIC nicely after a little bit of inside sanding. I tried it on a friend's YETI mug, and it didn't go up as high. You may need to scale a few percent to get it to sit at your desired height.

title: Camera dolly wheel mount for skateboard wheels

description.text:
was looking to build a cheap camera dolly using one of the many skateboard wheel/PVC pipe based designs out there so I designed this mount instead of trying to use angle brackets or PVC. Supports wheels with 8mm axles. I used the following hardware:

m8 50mm hex bolts
m8 nuts

You could change bolt lengths and add spacers/washers between the wheel and mount to accommodate a wide range of pipe sizes (the photo shows with and without a washer). Just print 4 of these, bolt them onto an MDF or plywood baseplate, and mount the wheels. Choose angled metal, PVC, ABS, or conduit pipes and go shoot!

author: emrfixit

title: Nut and Bolt Cutouts M2 + M3 (OpenSCAD Library)

description.text:
Please see the GitHub repository.

Nut and Bolt Cutouts

This library provides printable profiles of nuts and bolts. Currently, it includes M2 and M3 profiles.

The tolerance and part constants are based on empirical measurements from a digital caliper, using machine head metric nuts/screws/bolts, and from prints on my QIDI printer with various ABS filaments.

A calibration object for tuning this to your hardware is included as MetricCalibrationPlate.scad.

In my case, I have found that a tolerance (extra space around edges of profiles) of 0.1 millimeters results in tight fitting parts that aren't difficult to insert, and 0.2 millimeters results in a loose fitting part.

Usage

The intended usage is to use this library for difference cutouts:

use <Metric/M3.scad>;

$fs = 0.5;
$fa = 2;

w = 10;
h = 10;

difference() {
  translate([-w/2, -w/2, -h])
  cube([w, w, h]);

  BoltM3(l=15);
}

Inset

By default, all parts have their origin extending in the negative Z direction, with the head of the part at [0, 0, 0]. You can place the head above the X-Y plane by specifying the optional parameter inset=0

use <Metric/M3.scad>;

$fs = 0.5;
$fa = 2;

w = 10;
h = 10;

difference() {
  translate([-w/2, -w/2, -h])
  cube([w, w, h]);

  BoltM3(l=15, inset=0);
}

Parts

use <Metric/M3.scad>;
use <Metric/M2.scad>;

$fs = 0.5;
$fa = 2;

BoltM3();

translate([0, -10, 0])
NutM3();

translate([10, 0, 0])
BoltM2();

translate([10, -10, 0])
NutM2();

Inset

No Inset

bottle-1
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7nWXLSMvTWL

module spline
Simple list of points is turned to soft spline passing through all points
point formats
[x,y,z] or [x,y,z,scale] or [x,y,z,[xscale,yscale,zscale]]
or [x,y,z,scale/[xscale,yscale,zscale],[r,g,b]]
Children
If spline has zero children a stand in sphere(1) will be appointed.
for children Z+ is the sweeping direction.

https://openscadsnippetpad.blogspot.com/

Now the powerful part is to do things your self
format of points can be extended by any dimension or anything that tickle your fancy.
its really format agnostic. why not profiles? Mind that every point in the list has to have exactly the same format.

convert your ListOfPoints to spl format v2spl(ListOfPoints)
Spl is simply a list of four point bezier segments.

use spl2(HowFarAlong,SplListOfPoints); directly to query the spline.

I usually do HowFarAlong as a 0-1 but that makes very many calls to len3spl(SplListOfPoints).

instead you do one len3spl(SplListOfPoints). and calculate your HowFarAlong point on spline and do your thing. the precision of len3spl is turned down to ten steps per segment for speed you find it in function len3bz()

spl2(HowFarAlong,SplListOfPoints) returns a point in same format as you made your list

spl2euler(HowFarAlong,SplListOfPoints) expect first three values to be [x,y,z... and returns rotations like [0,Inclination ,Azimuth] . Steep inclinations will have the usual euler discontinuity flip artifacts around zenith. workaround for now is to design on x or y axis and rotate up 90 degrees.

comments.text:
Oh bronze. A lost wax mold is perfect for a high detail indented bronze ribbon. Unless you want hundreds then i suggest cold-cast bronze in one-piece silicone mold.
If by help someone mean discussing some code they work on, sure i help. If help means, like most help request i get, teaching or doing the hole thing for them, then no i don't do that.
But honestly i'm hesitant to assist because i belive open-scad is the wrong tool for anything beyond a fun brainteaser and mostly a wasteful detour from your stated goals.

description.text:
Recently I have rediscovered a part of my childhood with playing my old NES and SNES games. After multiple hours of fun reliving my past there was one issue for both systems, my hands are to large for the old controllers. This SNES controller grip feels more like a Playstation or XBOX controller in your hand which is what I have grown accustom to. It is also more ergonomic than the original as well. Hope you enjoy it as much as I have!

Update
Added second file with two holes for easy release of controller from grip.

comments.text: i noticed this aswell i assumed it was a slicing glitch, in addition this model has issues regarding dissapation of heat. i.e it contains it really well, wich is the direct oposite of what it is meant to. this thing will cause a thermal failure due to heat buildup behind the heatsink fan. in other words, it will trip the thermistor and cause a failure while heating up if a new print is started directly after another one. the idea is sound there is simply too much heat build up. stock hotend 2017 version of the tarantula.

title: Customizable Glass Plate Clip for Flashforge

description.text:
Updated so you can change the length of each side of the clip independently. I wanted the side to be shorter than the back to keep from hitting my custom internal spool holder. In general, the Back Right/Front Left clips will be the same and the Back Left/Front Right clips will be the same so I made a single variable that you can change so it just reverses the the measurements of the Front Right and Back Left variables so you don't have to change them all for the other side.

Make sure you use ABS to print these for a heated build plate so they don't melt!

This is a customizable glass plate clip. I remixed it from Customizable FlashForge glass bed corner by markwal and made it more customizable. This one allows you to resize almost everything.

You can mount this over the top of the existing nut on the build plate and add another nut/wing nut to keep the clips in place. I use a clip on each corner to keep the glass secure. The tabs allow for glass that doesn't quite cover the build plate. You can set the size for each of the two tabs separately to get a nice centered and tight fit. The tabs press up against the glass tightly, they do not clip the glass down. The tabs should be level with the top of the glass or just below it (not above the glass plate) or the clips will interfere with the print head.

Make sure the tabs are not above the glass or they will interfere with the print head!

Adding an extra nut to the bolt works better then removing and reusing the existing nut. If you try to reuse the existing nut, you cannot tighten the nut with the glass on the build plate since the bolt will turn...making it really hard to put the clips on correctly so the glass will be centered and the clips are tight against the glass.

The included files work perfectly for my Dreamer with this glass plate: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B019VPY9VK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1. If you have the same exact setup, you will need 2 of each clip. When installing the clips, align the clip so the smallest tab is at front/back and the biggest tab is at the side (There is a bigger size discrepancy on the sides with this particular glass plate).

You should also have 4 M3 nuts or wing nuts. You can check the case that came with the Dreamer for extra nuts... I think it came with spares. But I think the wing nuts will be better in the long run to re-tighten as they loosen up over time.

If you do not have the exact same setup, then make sure you put your glass plate in the center of the build plate and measure the amount of gap on each side if the glass is smaller.... then enter the numbers into the customizer for tab_right and tab_left. The left and right correspond to the clip when looking at the open end. So this will be the side or front/back amount of space depending on which corner the clip is going on. If your glass plate is a perfect fit for your build plate, you can put zero for tab_right and tab_left or maybe 1 if you want to have a tighter fit. Also be sure to check the height/thickness of your glass plate and change the number in Customizer if needed.

Make sure you print one of the Z-Axis spacers so you don't have the print head crunch down into the glass!

Flashforge Dreamer

No

Resolution:

35%

I used the Standard ABS setting in FlashPrint and changed the infill.

title: Dodge Center Wheel Cap - Durango Dakota Ram

description.text: When the 3rd of 4 OEM wheel caps fell out of my 2003 Dodge Durango, I felt that this would be a fun 3D project to take on. This design has a slightly raised ram emblem on it, and is rounded similar to the original design. I think you'll agree that this looks a ton better than the empty hole I had (and see all over town). I hope it helps you out as well.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

FIne

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed some successfully without rafts, but my final ones all had rafts as the black filament I was using wasn't adhering to the hot bed as well as the white prototypes.

1) I have the bottom connected in a ring to make it more solid during printing, once removed, you need to cut the small connection between the tabs so they can flex as they're pressed into the wheel opening.
2) I printed in black (other colors could be interesting... neon anyone?) and painted that raised ram image with a metallic paint, and then clear coated the entire cap prior to popping into the wheel of my truck.

These fit my 2003 Dodge Durango. Per postings on the internet, they should fit other vehicles as well... (I cannot guarantee, so print one and try it)

1996-2008 Dodge Ram 1500 (not all versions use this cap, please verify)
1996-2004 Dodge Ram 2500 (not all versions use this cap, please verify)
1996-2004 Dodge Ram 3500 (not all versions use this cap)
1998-2007 Dodge Durango
1997-2008 Dodge Dakota (not all versions use this cap)

title: Micro SD Card Reader Bracket w/Filament Bar

description.text:
My Anet A6 has a poorly positioned Micro SD card reader, which is on the main board and hard to get to... so I purchased a 25cm extension cable and wanted to mount the new card reader at the top of the printer.

I've uploaded the right side bracket (same as the original, but just the single bracket), to use on the right side of the filament feeder bar.

Please see the original filament feeder (I remixed this from) for the brackets without the card reader. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1780416

As I already had a specialized bar running across the top of the printer to allow easy feeding of filament, I simply modified one of those brackets to make it perform 2 functions.

I designed some supports into this design... they're very small... it printed successfully without additional supports, but were I to make them again, I'd make the supports within my design a little larger.

As noted in my comment (reply), I bought my extension cable direct from China... it took 2+ weeks to arrive, but was very inexpensive with free shipping.

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/2016-New-Arrive-TF-to-micro-SD-card-Flex-Extension-cable-Extender-Adapter-reader-car-GPS/32657854725.html?spm=2114.01010208.3.2.JtUYj9&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_2_10065_10068_10069_10017_10080_10082_10081_10060_10061_10062_10056_10055_10054_9998_10059_10078_10079_10073_10070_421_420_10052_10053_10050_10051,searchweb201603_3&btsid=00599aa8-663d-47fd-8b1d-2c936c0f8f85

This is showing 60cm, but I'm pretty sure mine was 25cm and was sufficient).

title: Horizontal Phone Stand for Video Viewing (now Customizer ready)

description.text:
I wanted a nice looking stand that looked interesting when the phone wasn't in it... and was small. It needed to hold my phone in a horizontal position for viewing.

Original Design: (8-5mm STL file)
The slot in the feet holds a phone who's thickness (at the edges) is <8.5mm thick.
(8-5mm STL file). As previously noted, the design could easily be resized to hold a larger phone (see below).

Update:
I had a friend who wanted to use with his phone case... I modified the design to allow a 13mm thickness as well (13mm STL file)

Update (10-22-2016)
Added a 22mm wide variant STL for someone with a big phone case.

Update (10-15-2016)
I had wanted to learn OpenSCAD, so as a first project, I decided to re-create this design in OpenSCAD and make it available for the Customizer.

You can select your phone thickness (8mm to 15mm) and the base will accomodate by making the slot wider and adjusting the angle in which it sits to allow the back of your phone to lean against the backrest sphere.

Disclaimer - I haven't tried to print one from the OpenSCAD / Customizer. If you use the customizer and make one, please let me know how it works so I can try and improve it as required. Thanks.

title: Square Cookie Cutter with Stamped Design

description.text:
This is a 60mm square Cookie Cutter, with a customizable Stamp, perfect for gingerbread and other types of cookies.

This is easily printed in 3 parts without waste and without supports

1) The Square (60mm) Cookie Cutter
2) The stamp Handle (which prints upright)
3) The Stamp, which is designed to print with 2 holes on the bottom (the handle snaps into, may require a slight filing / sanding) and the design (now a Tree) on the top.

I am including the 123D file for the stamp, so you can remove my current design, and build up any other design you'd like to use. You can make additional handles for each stamp, or use a single handle across multiple stamps.

Note: I've replaced the earlier stamp (still pictured) which was made for my daughter's organization, and am now including a "Tree" stamp. I am still including the 123D file, so you can continue to customize it as you like.

Happy baking.

description.text:
I like the design of the uStepper Robotic Arm so much I have started to build one. Unfortunately for my preference, it has limited wrist movement.

I use a 28BYJ-48 12V stepper for the angular wrist movement and a micro geared stepper for the rotational movement..

This is only a prototype for now, basically proof of concept. The only down side is the 28BYJ stepper looses position when the power is removed. I am going to look into using some type of gear reduction for the angular movement and some how reduce the mass of the end-effector

This 28BYJ stepper or similar:

title: 127T change gear for cutting metric threads on a Harrison L5 lathe

description.text:
The 127T gear is necessary for cutting metric threads on the imperial Harrison L5 lathe. (12.7mm is precisely ½" so 127T gives an exact conversion). Other gears needed to cover almost the full range of metric thread pitches are 40T,50T, 60T and 63T. I remixed this from my previous Harrison gear code that uses customiser to allow you to dial up the number of teeth you want. I would not recommend running with plastic on plastic but I have run 3D printed gears against steel gears for a while now and they seem to work fine.

Update: See my remix of this (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1808219) if you already have a 100T gear and never want to use both 100T and 127T at the same time. The remix uses less plastic, is quicker to print and can be printed on a 150mm square bed piece by piece or all at once on a 200mm square bed. Which is easier to make? I'll post another update once I have made the 127T-100T remix. I think the full 127T gear would be more convenient if you want to switch between metric and imperial thread cutting.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Steelfence

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No
Superglue the parts together.

This remix uses puzzlecut to slice the full gear into 3 pieces to make it compatible with 3D printers with a 200mm square build plate. I would suggest doing a couple of test prints to ensure that they key together OK first. I used my slicer software to trim the height to 3mm for the test prints. There is a kerf variable in the openscad file that can be edited to increase or decrease the spacing between the puzzle pieces. You can comment out all but the desired part in OpenSCAD and compile and save them in turn or you can do as I did and save the STL with all 3 parts in it and manually edit the output STL file with netfabb to split it into three separate files. The -0.05mm kerf that I used was pretty tight - needing a bit of filing and sanding to make it fit. I didn't use any glue - just pressed the parts together with a vise.

comments.text: Outstanding! A very pragmatic solution to the shortage of 127 tooth wheels for the Harrison lathe.  Printing this this week.
comments.author: rhillman

comments.text: I'd be interested to read about your make of this.  I am printing the largest segment as I type.  I have an original steel 127T myself, but I enjoy a challenge and a plastic 127T might be a cheaper thing to make and to ship (than steel) to someone who does not have one.

author: Andrew-_-Fineman

description.text:
Part pictured on this page:
http://north-america.beyerdynamic.com/shop/hah/spare-parts/schieber-reparatur-set.html

This item replaces the large plastic pieces on the uppermost portion of that image.
They are not perfect, but they work.
Use the screws supplied with your Beyerdynamic headphones; they already have a plastic tapping cut in them.

Print:
Use Supports
25% fill
0.8mm wall thickness [2 perimeters for 0.4mm nozzle).

Installation:
Thread the screws ALL THE WAY into the piece with the inset pieces for the screws. Then line the piece up with screws installed with the two metal mounting brackets on your headset that have the holes for the screws. Ensure the adjustment slider on the central metal piece on which the speaker is mounted is within its space on the plastic mounting bracket.

Then while holding this together tightly, get the second piece with the smaller holes in it and place it tightly against the first piece with the screws through the metal mounting brackets on the crossbar/headrest. You should be able to do this with your thumb and index finger. Correctly done, everything should be lined up now.

Then back out the screws with your free hand halfway. Thread them back in, and they should lock with the far piece. At that, you should be done.

The inset screw piece is typically placed on the interior of the headset, with the thicker piece with smaller holes facing exterior the headset.

Headphones This Will Work For:
BEYERDYNAMIC
DT 790 / DT 797 / DT 770 / DT 770 PRO / DT 770 PRO HT / DT 880 / DT 880 PRO / DT 880 PRO HT / DT 990 / DT 990 PRO / HS 200 Dyn / HS 200 Rotor / HS 200 Trend / HS 400

title: Restraining Bolt for R2-D2 and Other Droids

description.text:
While this is technically not an accessory for the dome (or a remix of it) I thought it would probably make the most sense to post this here. There are a couple of other restraining bolts on Thingiverse, but I wasn't quite satisfied with them. In particular, I wanted to include the knurling on the base. Plus, this seemed like an object that my relatively modest modeling skills could handle. I made it in Tinkercad. I originally just guessed at the dimensions, but I was given some accurate numbers recently (May 2017) so I've added a revised version of the bolt that should be closer to accurate. I left a hole in the bottom so you can put a 10mm x 4mm magnet in it. I'll leave the original version as well in case anyone needs it.

This shouldn't require any supports with the possible exception of the hole in the bottom. Everything else, including the groove around the edge, will print fine without supports. I would print it at the finest layer height possible.

title: Steep Macbook Stand (Retina)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: I needed a stand that would let me keep the laptop screen closer to my eyes. I couldn't read small text on some files. I created this customizable stand to lift the laptop higher, and at a steeper angle, that way I could keep it closer without interfering with the keyboard. It's pretty stable. It's also designed to minimize filament use. No need for a large stand, when you can have 2 smaller ones.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Just print on it's side on high settings.
2 stands is more than enough, but feel free to try more if you like.

comments.text: Hi, I really like this design and use a version of it at work, as do several of my colleagues. I found that the new MacBook Pros don't open quite as far as the old ones and I had to remix it slightly to lay the laptop back a bit. However, your license specifies "no derivatives" so I'm unable to make the remixed version available (at least that's my reading of the license). I was wondering it you'd change to license to remove this term, I'm not looking to sell these, just to make my version available.

title: 3-wheeled Z guide (Re-D-Bot)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi all! (=

This is my 3-wheeled mount for Z-axis. So you can save 1 wheel instead use original 4-wheel. Also by 3 wheel much easier calibrate. In files you can see two versions.

First version has 2 parts (Z_Wheel3_Guide-Part1 and Z_Wheel3Guide-Part2...) where part 2 can be used with tensioner or eccentric.

Second version (Z_Wheel3_Guidev2...) is more stronger and prefered by me. I recommend to use this version. But there version only with tensioner. I like tensioner there, it so useful and easy.

P'S: On Re-D-Bot and D-Bot analogs, used Micro V Wheels.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Re-D-Bot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%
For tensioner you will need one M5*15 (or some M5 suitable length) and one M5 nut.

+1 mm to outside, for more easy assembly

Updated files:

  • Z_Wheel3_Guide_v2-With_tensioner.STL

If you want to support me and if you want to get cashbacks on Aliexpress, check this
http://epngo.bz/cashback_index/v1nphb

I like their service, on Aliexpress you can get double cashback (about 18%)

comments.text:
Hey Nick,
Tried printing the v2 but failed twice. There is a weird slope you have on the bottom of the part where the tensioner slot is, the corners of that slope would curl up and hit the probe on my I3, at layer 3 or 4 (.2 layer height). More of a printer issue than the design I guess, but I was wondering if that slope has any functionality and it doesn't look to me like it does, so maybe you would consider just getting rid of that slope and have the bottom surface flat like the previous versions.
Anyway I'm printing the 2 part version with tensioner now, without any issues.
Thanks for the awesome designs.

author: haifisch1896

description.text:
These inexpensive Chinese electronic calipers are power hogs. Also they do not shut off when you press OFF. The only thing that turns off is the display.

Since the display uses virtually no power, about 99.9% of battery power is wasted while it sits on a shelf. Instead of lasting for a few years, the battery expires in a short amount of time.

I sometimes don't use this caliper for months, and got tired of discovering weak and dead batteries. I looked for an easy way to disconnect the battery, but didn't see anything. Remove the battery.... but where do you store it?

This little clip is a handy place to store the battery. The clip should be a nice, tight fit so it can't accidentally slip off. It may need to be scaled up or down one-percent or thereabouts.

10 min 3 grams ABS at 0.3mm Z. Experiment to get the size perfect.

Metric and SAE files provided.
